g.text: Safety office at the University of California provided
Nanotechnology: Guidelines for safe research practices
Office of Environment, Health & Safety at the University
as their publication for the Ber-
Energy, Nanoscale Science Research Centers, updated
Robert-Sauvé en santé et en securité du travail (IRSST)
The Environmental Health and Safety office of Massa-
ging the Health and Safety Concerns Associated with
handling and disposal of manufactured nanomaterials
in 2007, as their publication PD 6699-2:2007, ICS Num-
American Society for Testing and Materials prepared
Standard Guide for Handling Unbound Engineered
dards/E2535.htm]. This is a guide for use when no
specific information on ENMs or toxicity is available.
guidance is designed for lab scale (i.e., not industrial)
The Center for High-Rate Nanomanufacturing and
NIOSH are preparing a guide to safe practices for work-
ing with nanomaterials that is anticipated to be released
Some websites that have considerable information on
nanoscale materials are Nano Safe at [http://www.
nanosafe.org], The International Council on Nanotech-
An extensive variety of ENMs has been created. ENMs
have already been utilized in many products and much
more extensive use is anticipated in the future. There
exposure to many ENMs, albeit often after very high
doses, and generally lacking dose-response assessment.
There is a small amount of exposure assessment infor-
mation, and a paucity of information required for a risk
characterization. Until more research and workplace
monitoring information becomes available to refine the
current knowledge of ENM risks, good workplace prac-
tices and guidelines based on ultrafine materials are
guiding the occupational safety and health practices in
- Post signs indicating potential hazards, PPE
entrances to areas where ENMs are handled.
- Use appropriate PPE as a precaution whenever fail-
ure of a control, such as an engineering control,
could result in ENM exposure, or ensure that engi-
neering controls notify workers (e.g., alarms) when
PPE generally includes closed-toed shoes, long pants
without cuffs, long-sleeved shirt, laboratory coat,
nitrile gloves, eye protection and perhaps a respira-
tor, e.g., a half-mask P-100 or one that provides a
higher level of protection, as appropriate to the
- Transfer ENMs between workstations in closed,
- Avoid handling ENMs in the open air in a
- Store dispersible ENMs, suspended in liquids or in
a dry particle form, in closed (tightly sealed) contain-
- Clean work areas potentially contaminated with
ENMs at the end of each work shift, at a minimum,
using either a HEPA-filtered vacuum cleaner or wet
wiping methods. Do not dry sweep or use com-
- Consider the use of disposable absorbent bench
- Place sticky floor mat at exit.
- Provide facilities for hand-washing, showering and
Prohibit food, beverages and smoking in the work
Journal of Occupational Medicine and Toxicology
